billEvents.eventText: REFERRED TO HOUSING, CONSTRUCTION AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT

title: Requires landlords to make certain records available upon request of the rent guidelines board
summary: Requires landlords to make books and records available regarding income and other certain information upon request of the rent guidelines board to be used in determining whether certain rents for housing accommodations within a city having a population of one million or more shall be adjusted; requires the rent guidelines board to keep such information confidential; and authorizes the rent guidelines board to administer oaths, issue subpoenas and perform other certain duties.

BILL NUMBER:S2258

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the administrative code of the city of New York and the
emergency tenant protection act of nineteen seventy-four, in relation to
the powers of the rent guidelines board

PURPOSE:
This bill requires landlords to make certain
records
available upon the request of the rent guidelines board.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
Section 1 of this bill amends
subdivision b of
section 26-510 of the administrative code of the city of New York.
Upon request by the rent guidelines board, landlords regulated by the
emergency tenant protection act of 1974 shall make available any
books and records regarding income, expenditures, tax benefits,
financing arrangements, utility bills, and any other pertinent
information to determine rent adjustments. This shall only apply to
cities with a population of one million or more.

Section 2 adds a new subdivision j to section 26-510 of the
administrative code of the city of New York. The rent guidelines
board shall be authorized to administer oaths, issue subpoenas,
conduct investigations, and designate officers to hear reports on
behalf of the board.

Section 3 amends subdivision c of section 4 of chapter 576 of the laws
of 1974. Upon request by the rent guidelines board, landlords
regulated by the administrative code of the city of New York shall
make available any books and records regarding income, expenditures,
tax benefits, financing arrangements, utility bills, and any other
pertinent information to determine rent adjustments. This shall only
apply to cities with a population of one million or more. All
information provided shall be subject to the freedom of information
law.

The rent guidelines board shall be authorized to administer oaths,
issue subpoenas, conduct investigations, and designate officers to
hear reports on behalf of t,he board.

Section 4 enacts this bill immediately.

JUSTIFICATION:
The RSL and ETPA require that rent
guidelines for
stabilized apartments be promulgated annually based on the economic
condition of the residential real estate industry. In practice,

however, this mandate has been carried out by rent guidelines boards
in ways which do not accurately assess the necessity for rent
adjustments. The New York City rent guidelines board has based rent
adjustments on an annual survey of vendor costs (fuel, labor, parts,
insurance, etc.)
with no analysis either of what landlords actually spend for these
items or how much rental income they earn. The suburban boards have
based rent adjustments on an unverified annual survey of costs and
income.

For the first time, this legislation requires that rent adjustments
are based on actual increases in landlords' costs of maintaining
their properties. Landlords should base need for rental increases on
increased costs of maintenance and costs of improvements. Rental
increases can thereby be justified after a review of the records
indicating these increased costs of business.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
New bill.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect immediately following the
expiration of certain provisions of the rent stabilization and
emergency tenant protection act.
